column2: Polish: [ˈkʲɛltsɛ] (listen)) is a city in south-central Poland with 194
column3: 852 inhabitants. It has been the capital of the Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship (Holy Cross Province) since 1999 and used to be the capital of its predecessor
column5: 1945–1998). The city is in the middle of the Świętokrzyskie Mountains (Holy Cross Mountains)
column6: on the banks of the Silnica River
column7: in the northern part of the historical Polish province of Lesser Poland.

column1: Kielce has a history back over 900 years
column2: and the exact date that it was founded remains unknown. Kielce was once an important centre of limestone mining and the vicinity is famous for its natural resources like copper
column3: lead and iron
column5: over the centuries
column6: were exploited on a large scale. There are several fairs and exhibitions held in Kielce throughout the year. The city and its surroundings are also known for their historic architecture
column7: green spaces and recreational areas like the Świętokrzyski National Park.

column1: According to a local legend Mieszko II Lambert
column2: son of Boleslaus I of Poland
column3: dreamt he was attacked by a band of brigands in a forest. In the dream he saw a vision of Saint Adalbert who drew a winding line which turned into a stream. When Mieszko woke up
column4: he found the Silnica River whose waters helped him regain strength. He also discovered huge white tusks of an unknown animal. Mieszko announced he would build a town and a church to St. Adalbert at that site. According to this legend
column5: the town's name Kielce commemorates the mysterious tusks (kieł in Polish). Various other legends exist to explain the name's origin. One states that the town was named after its founder who belonged to the noble family of Kiełcz
column6: while another claims that it stems from the Celts who may have lived in the area in previous centuries. Other theories connect the town's name to occupational names relating to mud huts
column7: iron tips for arrows and spears
column9: a settlement of tar makers).The most probable etymology traces the origins of the name to an Old Polish noun kielce (plural form of kielec
column10: "sprout") and refers to plants sprouting in the wetlands where the settlement was located.  The earliest extant document referring to the settlement by the name of Kielce dates to 1213.

column1: The area of Kielce has been inhabited since at least the 5th century BC. Until the 6th or 7th century the banks of the Silnica were inhabited by Celts. They were driven out by a Lechitic tribe of Vistulans who started hunting in the nearby huge forests and had settled most of the area now known as Lesser Poland and present-day Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship. The lands of Wiślanie were at first subdued by Bohemia
column2: however they soon came under the control of the Piast dynasty and became a part of Poland.

column1: The area of the Holy Cross Mountains was almost unpopulated until the 11th century when the first hunters established permanent settlements at the outskirts of the mountains. They needed a place to trade furs and meat for grain and other necessary products
column2: and so the market of Kielce was formed. In the early 12th century the new settlement became a property of the Bishops of Kraków
column3: who built a wooden church and a manor. In 1171 a stone church was erected by bishop Gedeon Gryf. During the times of Wincenty Kadłubek a parochial school in Kielce was opened in 1229. By 1295 the town was granted city rights. In the mid-13th century the town was destroyed by the Mongol invasion of Ögedei Khan

column1: The area around Kielce was rich in minerals such as copper ore
column2: lead ore
column3: and iron
column4: as well as limestone. In the 15th century Kielce became a significant centre of metallurgy. There were also several glass factories and armourer shops in the town. In 1527 bishop Piotr Tomicki founded a bell for the church and between 1637 and 1642 Manierist palace was erected near the market place by Bishop Jakub Zadzik. It is one of the very few examples of French Renaissance architecture in Poland and the only example of a magnate's manor from the times of Vasa dynasty to survive World War II.

column1: During The Deluge the town was pillaged and burnt by the Swedes. Only the palace and the church survived
column2: but the town managed to recover under the rule of bishop Andrzej Załuski. By 1761 Kielce had more than 4
column3: 000 inhabitants. In 1789 Kielce were nationalized and the burgers were granted the right to elect their own representatives in Sejm. Until the end of the century the city's economy entered a period of fast growth. A brewery was founded as well as several brick factories
column5: hospital.

column1: As a result of the 3rd Partition the town was annexed by Austria. During the Polish-Austrian War of 1809 it was captured by prince Józef Poniatowski and joined with the Napoleon controlled Duchy of Warsaw
column2: but after the fall of Napoleon Bonaparte in 1815 it was joined with the Russian controlled Kingdom of Poland. For a brief period when Kraków was an independent city-state (Republic of Kraków)
column3: Kielce became the capital of the Kraków Voivodeship. Thanks to the efforts by Stanisław Staszic Kielce became the centre of the newly established Old-Polish Industrial Zone (Staropolski Okręg Przemysłowy). The town grew quickly as new mines
column4: quarries and factories were constructed. In 1816 the first Polish technical university was founded in Kielce. However
column5: after Staszic's death the Industrial Zone declined and in 1826 the school was moved to Warsaw and became the Warsaw University of Technology.

column1: In 1830 many of the inhabitants of Kielce took part in the November Uprising against Russia. In 1844
column2: priest Piotr Ściegienny began organising a local revolt to liberate Kielce from the Russian yoke
column3: for which he was sent to Siberia. In 1863 Kielce took part in the January Uprising. As a reprisal for insubordination the tsarist authorities closed all Polish schools and turned Kielce into a military garrison city. The Polish language was banned. Because of these actions many gymnasium students took part in the 1905 Revolution and were joined by factory workers.

column1: After the outbreak of World War I
column2: Kielce was the first Polish city to be liberated from Russian rule by the Polish Legions under Józef Piłsudski. After the war when Poland regained its independence after 123 years of Partitions
column3: Kielce became the capital of Kielce Voivodeship. The plans to strengthen Polish heavy and war industries resulted in Kielce becoming one of the main nodes of the Central Industrial Area (Centralny Okręg Przemysłowy). The town housed several big factories
column4: among them the munitions factory "Granat" and the food processing plant "Społem".

column1: During the Polish Defensive War of 1939
column2: the main portion of the defenders of Westerplatte as well as the armoured brigade of General Stanisław Maczek were either from Kielce or from its close suburbs. During the occupation that lasted for most of the Second World War
column3: the city was an important centre of resistance. There were several resistance groups active in the town
column4: including Armia Krajowa (AK) and Gwardia Ludowa (GL).

column1: Notable acts of resistance included theft of 2 tons of TNT from the "Społem" factory run by the Nazis
column2: which were then used by the partisans to make hand grenades. Also
column3: the daring escape from jail in Kielce of a dozen or so AK members
column4: organized in November 1942 by Stanisław Depczyński. Not to mention
column5: a grenade attack by a unit of the GL on the Smoleński coffee shop
column6: killing 6 Germans including a major in the SS (February 1943)
column7: as well as the assassination of the noted Gestapo informant Franz Wittek on 15 June 1944
column8: by a unit under Second Lt. Kazimierz Smolak on the corner of Solna and Paderewski Streets. One of the attackers died during the attack and a further four lost their lives not long afterwards. This was not the first assassination attempt against Wittek. In 1942
column9: Henryk Pawelec fired at him in the market square
column10: but his pistol misfired. In February 1943
column11: a unit under the command of Stanisław Fąfar shot at Wittek by the Seminarium building. Wittek
column13: survived. Successful assassinations of local collaborators
column14: including the shooting of Jan Bocian took place in broad daylight at a shop in Bodzentyńska Street. Similar was the attack on the factory of C. Wawrzyniak in March 1943
column15: terrorizing and disarming the volksdeutscher workers and destroying the machinery
column16: as well as the attack on the HASAG factory in May 1943 and the takeover of the Kielce Herbskie railway station.Moreover
column17: the hills and forests of Holy Cross Mountains became a scene of heavy partisan activity. A small town of Pińczów located some 30 kilometres (19 miles) from Kielce became the capital of the so-called Pinczów Republic
column18: a piece of Polish land controlled by the partisans. The "Jodla" Świętokrzyskie Mountains Home Army fought against the Germans long before Operation Tempest inflicted heavy casualties on the occupying forces and later took part in the final liberation of their towns and cities in January 1945. During the war
column19: many of inhabitants of Kielce lost their lives. Today
column20: Kielce is a rapidly developing city of growing regional importance.

column1: Prior to the 1939 Invasion of Poland
column2: like many other cities across the Second Polish Republic
column3: Kielce had a significant Jewish population. According to the Russian census of 1897
column5: 200 inhabitants
column7: 400 Jews in Kielce (around 27 percent). On the eve of the Second World War there were about 18
column8: 000 Jews in the city. Between the onset of war and March 1940
column9: the Jewish population of Kielce expanded to 25
column11: with trains of dispossessed Jews arriving under the escort of German Order Police battalions from the Polish areas annexed by Nazi Germany.Immediately after the German occupation of Poland in September 1939
column12: all Jews were ordered to wear a Star of David on their outer garments. Jewish–owned factories in Kielce were confiscated by the Gestapo
column13: stores and shops along the main thoroughfares liquidated
column14: and ransom fines introduced. The forced labour and deportations to concentration camps culminated in mass extermination of Jews of Kielce during the Holocaust in occupied Poland.

column2: the Kielce Ghetto was formed
column3: surrounded by high fences
column5: and guards. The gentile Poles were ordered to vacate the area and the Jews were given one week to relocate. The ghetto was split in two
column6: along Warszawska Street (Nowowarszawska) with the Silnica River (pl) running through it. The so-called large ghetto was set up between the streets of Orla
column10: and the smaller ghetto between Warszawska on the west
column13: and the St. Wojciech square. The ghetto gates were closed on 5 April 1941; the Jewish Ghetto Police was formed with 85 members and ordered to guard it. Meanwhile
column14: expulsions elsewhere and deportations to Kielce continued until August 1942 at which time there were 27
column15: 000 prisoners crammed in the ghetto. Trains with Jewish families arrived from the entire Kielce Voivodeship
column20: and outbreaks of epidemic typhus took the lives of 4
column21: 000 people before mid-1942. During this time
column22: many of them were forced to work at a nearby German munition plant run by Hasag. In August 1942
column23: the Kielce Ghetto was liquidated in the course of only five days. During roundups
column24: all Jews unable to move were shot on the spot including the sick
column28: 000 Jews were led into waiting Holocaust trains
column29: and murdered in the gas chambers of Treblinka. After the extermination action only 2
column31: lodged in the labour camp at Stolarska and Jasna Streets (pl) within the small ghetto. Those who survived were sent to other forced labour camps. On May 23
column33: the Kielce cemetery massacre was perpetrated by the German police; 45 Jewish children who had survived the Kielce Ghetto liquidation
column34: were murdered by Order Police battalions.

column3: the local Jewish gathering of some 200 Holocaust survivors from the Planty 7 Street refugee centre of the Zionist Union became the target of the Kielce pogrom in which 37 (40) Jews (17–21 of whom remain unidentified) and 2 ethnic Poles were killed
column4: including 11 fatally shot with military rifles and 11 more stabbed with bayonets
column5: indicating direct involvement of Polish troops.During the Cold War
column6: many Jewish historians theorized that the pogrom became the cause of outward Jewish emigration from Poland immediately following the opening of the borders in 1947. Nevertheless
column7: the true reasons behind the dramatic increase of Jewish emigration from Poland were far more complex. The new government of the Communist Poland signed a repatriation agreement with the Soviet Union helping over 150
column8: 000 Holocaust survivors leave the Gulag camps legally. Poland was the only Eastern Bloc country to allow free and unrestricted Jewish Aliyah to the nascent State of Israel
column9: upon the conclusion of World War II. After the Kielce pogrom Gen. Spychalski of PWP signed a legislative decree allowing the remaining survivors to leave Poland without visas or exit permits. Poland was the only Eastern Bloc country to do so
column10: at war's end. Britain demanded from Poland (among others) to halt the Jewish exodus
column11: but their pressure was largely unsuccessful.

column1: Kielce is one of the relatively cooler cities in Poland.  It experiences four distinct seasons and has a warm summer subtype humid continental climate (Dfb)
column2: typical of this part of Europe.  It has cool
column3: cloudy winters with almost daily light snowfall and generally moderate temperatures within a few degrees of the freezing point
column4: and moderately warm and sunny summers
column5: with frequent but brief hot spells and abundant rainfall falling mostly during numerous and occasionally severe thunderstorms.  Surrounded by the Holy Cross Mountains
column7: the summer night time temperatures are somewhat cooler and the thunderstorms somewhat more frequent and severe than in surrounding areas of Poland.Both continental and maritime air masses can enter the area undergoing little modification
column8: resulting in striking differences in the seasons from year to year
column9: particularly in winter when the contrast between maritime and continental air is at its greatest.  Maritime influences from the Atlantic typically bring cool
column11: damp and often foggy weather both in summer and in winter
column12: whereas continental air masses often result in long periods of sunny and dry weather
column13: hot in summer and on occasion

column1: The highest temperature recorded in Kielce since 1971 is 36.4 °C (98 °F) and the lowest is −33.9 °C (−29 °F)
column2: giving the city a temperature range of 70.3 °C (126.5 °F)
column3: the second highest in Poland.  The city receives 1720 to 1829 hours of sunshine annually
column5: with a notably sunny spring and summer
column6: and a cloudy late autumn and winter.  Winds are generally very light throughout the year
column7: with an abundance of calm days
column9: cool temperatures often feel much milder than expected due to a relative lack of windchill
column10: especially during sunny spells in early spring
column11: as well as during severe winter cold snaps
column12: which are typically dominated by calm
column13: anticyclonic weather. Föhn winds from the Carpathian mountains do occasionally reach the city
column14: resulting in unusually mild temperatures for a semi-continental location at this latitude
column15: on rare occasions reaching approximately 15 °C (59 °F) in the winter months.

column1: Winter conditions are highly dependent on the source region of the air mass that dominates during a particular month
column2: resulting in tremendous variability from one year to the next.  For example
column3: in January 2006
column4: the city experienced typically continental winter weather
column5: resulting in an average daytime high of −3.7 °C (25 °F)
column6: recording a nighttime low of −30 °C (−22 °F) on the 24th.  The very next year
column8: the weather was predominantly of the Atlantic type
column9: resulting in an average high of 5.7 °C (42 °F) and occasional days above 10 °C (50 °F)
column10: more typical of coastal locations in Western Europe.  As a result of this variability
column11: severe cold with temperatures below −20 °C (−4 °F) can be completely absent during some winters
column14: even as late as March.  Heavy snowfall is rare
column15: and significant snow accumulations typically occur gradually
column16: a few centimeters at a time over a protracted cold spell.

column1: Summer is warm and lasts from June to early September
column2: and is characterized by abundant sunshine
column3: but also severe weather
column4: particularly early in the season.  Though temperatures average in the low-to-mid 20s (70s Fahrenheit)
column5: they are rather variable with frequent hot spells reaching approximately 30 °C (86 °F) interrupted by cold fronts
column6: which frequently bring violent thunderstorms and several days of cool and sometimes chilly weather.  Although hot weather is frequent and many summers experience a few oppressively hot days of around 35 °C (95 °F)
column7: summer temperatures in the city are never extreme and have not exceeded 36.4 °C (98 °F) in recent decades.

column1: The transitional seasons of spring and autumn are highly unpredictable and experience large temperature swings with periods of fine weather and temperatures around 20 °C (68 °F) as early as March and late into October
column2: alternating with much colder periods.  Sharp nighttime frosts can occur as early as September and as late as May
column3: though on calm
column5: it often warms up rapidly to approximately 20 °C (68 °F)
column8: accumulating snow can occur in October and April
column9: though mild weather rapidly returns.  The springtime month of May is notably the sunniest month of the year.
